discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Secret manager has automatic rotation

choices.A: Store the tokens in AWS Secrets Manager. Create an AWS Lambda function to perform the rotation.
choices.C: Store the tokens in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). Use an AWS managed key to perform the rotation.
choices.B: Store the tokens in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store. Create an AWS Lambda function to perform the rotation.
choices.D: Store the tokens in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). Use an AWS owned key to perform the rotation.

questions.question_text:
A company has an application that uses different APIs to generate embeddings for input text. The company needs to implement a solution to automatically rotate the API tokens every 3 months.
Which solution will meet this requirement?

discussion.content:
Explanation:

 Create a feature group: You first define the schema (features) of your dataset.

 Ingest the records: Populate the feature group with data.

 Access the store to build datasets for training: Retrieve the ingested data to use in training models.

Correct Steps (In Order):
✅ 1. Create a feature group.
✅ 2. Ingest the records.
✅ 3. Access the store to build datasets for training.

Why?
1️⃣ Create a Feature Group → Defines schema & storage for feature data.
2️⃣ Ingest Records → Stores data in the feature group.
3️⃣ Access Store → Retrieves features for model training.

Keywords to Remember:
✅ Feature Group → Defines structure
✅ Ingest Records → Store features
✅ Access Store → Retrieve for training

To create and manage features using Amazon SageMaker Feature Store, follow these steps:
1)Create a feature group : Organize your features by defining a feature group.
2)Ingest the records : Load the data into the feature group.
3)Access the store to build datasets for training : Retrieve the data from the feature group to prepare for model training.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
An ML engineer needs to use Amazon SageMaker Feature Store to create and manage features to train a model.
Select and order the steps from the following list to create and use the features in Feature Store. Each step should be selected one time. (Select and order three.)
• Access the store to build datasets for training.
• Create a feature group.
• Ingest the records.
//IMG//

An ML engineer receives datasets that contain missing values, duplicates, and extreme outliers. The ML engineer must consolidate these datasets into a single data frame and must prepare the data for ML.
Which solution will meet these requirements?

choices.B: Use Amazon SageMaker Ground Truth to import the datasets and to consolidate them into a single data frame. Use the human-in-the-loop capability to prepare the data.
choices.C: Manually import and merge the datasets. Consolidate the datasets into a single data frame. Use Amazon Q Developer to generate code snippets that will prepare the data.
choices.D: Manually import and merge the datasets. Consolidate the datasets into a single data frame. Use Amazon SageMaker data labeling to prepare the data.
choices.A: Use Amazon SageMaker Data Wrangler to import the datasets and to consolidate them into a single data frame. Use the cleansing and enrichment functionalities to prepare the data.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A: SageMaker Data Wrangler simplifies merging and cleaning datasets. (Correct answer)
B: Ground Truth is for labeling, not cleaning.
C: Manual merging is slow and inefficient.
D: Data Labeling adds labels but doesn’t clean data.

Selected Answer: A
This is basic use-case for data wrangler

Selected Answer: C
A. Anomaly detection: For rare events, not binary classification.
B. Linear regression: For predicting continuous numbers, not Yes/No.
C. Logistic regression: Perfect for Yes/No predictions (binary classification). --> RIGHT
D. Semantic segmentation: For images, not customer prediction.

questions.question_text:
A company has historical data that shows whether customers needed long-term support from company staff. The company needs to develop an ML model to predict whether new customers will require long-term support.
Which modeling approach should the company use to meet this requirement?

choices.C: The model must be registered in the SageMaker Model Registry.
choices.A: The ML engineer and the Canvas user must be in separate SageMaker domains.
choices.B: The Canvas user must have permissions to access the S3 bucket where the model artifacts are stored.
choices.D: The ML engineer must host the model on AWS Marketplace.
choices.E: The ML engineer must deploy the model to a SageMaker endpoint.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
For model outside of Amazon SageMaker, canvas user needs access to S3; Model --> Model registry

Selected Answer: BC
That's basic how Sagemaker works.

questions.question_text:
An ML engineer has developed a binary classification model outside of Amazon SageMaker. The ML engineer needs to make the model accessible to a SageMaker Canvas user for additional tuning.
The model artifacts are stored in an Amazon S3 bucket. The ML engineer and the Canvas user are part of the same SageMaker domain.
Which combination of requirements must be met so that the ML engineer can share the model with the Canvas user? (Choose two.)

exam.name: AWS Certified Machine Learning Engineer - Associate MLA-C01
